abstracts.cdata!:
Serbia has been putting its economy in
            order for the last decade after the disarray of the 1990s.
            Through reforms, the country restored macroeconomic
            stability and achieved high growth until 2008. But this came
            at a cost with the external debt reaching 79 percent of GDP
            in 2009. During the last three years, the Republic of Serbia
            has taken steps to improve its debt management capacity and
            has been trying to find ways to gain access to new and
            cheaper sources of funding with longer tenors. At the same
            time, the country has been pushing forward with a wide
            reform agenda, particularly aimed at improving the business
            environment for the private sector and at making the
            financial sector more stable and efficient.
